name: Reina Roja
Nasir Meidan
Near-Earth Hub
Refining the Foundry
description:
2-1 with this deck at a store tournament. Open scoring windows by trashing your opponent's programs. 12 ice but you won't need more. You're The Foundry. It's great.

We aren't playing NEXT ice because all we need is ETR ice and the cheapest barrier and code gate that fit that description both cost less than the similar NEXT ice.

We aren't playing any Bioroids because the runner will just click through, and that's not cool.

Our ice costs 33 to rez in total. Our ops generate 33 in total. Then we've got Melange and Reclamation Order to get more money. You do the math.

name: Replicating Perfection
Central Server Rush Deck
description:
This is a deck I made that's designed around being able to effectively run on central servers. Pretty much everything in this deck was put it in for reason to make runs as efficiently as possible.

I put John Masanori and Grifter in the deck to get additional draw-power and credits from making runs.

Unfortunately, I haven't been able to play to play too many games with this deck yet. For this reason, I don't know if the deck works as I designed it to yet.

I want I to have one more ice breaker in this deck that can run on remote servers just in case I need to.

I wanna get rid of Sneakdoor Beta. Also, I wanna swap out Akamatsu Mem Chip for Dyson Mem Chip.

Any other pieces of advice would be awesome and greatly appreciated.

name: All i need is virus 1.1 ;)
description: Take money from virus, trash card, eat ice and have fun. And remember, play fast and be agressive. 5 game 4 win (1 milling R&D)

name: The Moon is a Harsh Mistress
description: Big ICE HB deck with some tricks added in.

name: Disposable Breaking
description: Trying to build a deck around disposable icebreakers. Exile felt like the best runner for the situation.

name: Chaos Strike - Anti NBN FA
description:
The point of this deck is to rig up with exactly what you need and no more as quickly as possible and then hammer on centrals and remotes. I'm still tweaking it, but the deck is designed to just be agile and quick. That means that against Jinteki you're going to have a pretty rough time. Indexing will help with this, but it probably won't be enough.

Interfaces are really important when playing against NBN these days, you almost shouldn't be running centrals with out them; except that you have to or you'll lose. Be warry of grim. Mimic is a really efficient breaker, but grim will ruin your day if you don't have the suckers. (Keep atman & smc in mind if you're expecting that. 4/5 is a pretty good target for atman in this deck, 5 when against weyland so that archer only needs 1 counter)

Bank job is of course just awesome when playing against NBN. Their centrals used to be pretty damn porous, but these days the neutral ice package means you need breakers against every deck and therefor money.

You could lose pro-co & plascrete to really speed this beast up in certain ways, possibly turning a bank job into stim hacks. Kati is also a questionable include, but the fact is that you don't always draw testrunopus. Sometimes she fills a gap and sometimes she doesn't. That's another call. Otherwise I don't think there's much you can change unless you don't want to do the parasite thing, which is legitimate. Parasite could be nerve agent or another HQ interface. I think I'd personally take the interface or a legwork since NBN FA is somehow a taxing deck too. (ELI! WHY ARE YOU ONE INFLUENCE!?)

So, there are questionable includes, but this is a deck I built last fall for plugged-in tour when I wasn't as focused of a player. I've already made some tweaks to increase its quality, but I'll leave the rest up to the reader. There are so many threats now that I don't know if I could pick the "right" card for the deck. You'll notice there's only tutors to guard against will 'o the wisp, maybe you want redundancy on breakers?

Anyways, this deck does win against NBN. I just want to share it to maybe take some of the sting off playing against FA. There's still a lot of luck involved, but it happens.

name: Disposable Breaking
description: Trying to build a deck around disposable icebreakers. Exile felt like the best runner for the situation.

name: Retired, not dead, mk. II
description:
Playing Vamp in the middle game can completely turn the tables. With Iain's ability and Underworld Contact a start-of-turn income of 5 credits is quite common with this deck. The obvious Iain ingredients The Source and Fall Guy prolong the game so much that economy is no issue for the runner. Crypsis and Gorman Drip v1 are incentives for yet another turn of purging. You also keep installing resources, preferrably connections that can be used for Calling in Favors.

If you suspect that agendas pile up in HQ or generally want to improve your timing, check with Executive Wiretaps. For the late game use Sneakdoor Beta and HQ Interface. For runs on remotes you can prepare with Vamp or Account Siphon, recycle both with Same Old Thing.

If Caprice or Jackson bother you, pull the trigger on your Unregistered S&W '35.

This make includes helpful suggestions to the previous version like Hostage, The Helpful AI and Feedback Filter.

name: Person of Interest v3.0
description: Updated a previous PsychoBeale build to NEH from Making News. Scorched Earth comes up more frequently now, and there's a fairly steady source of econ from Marked Accounts and PAD Campaign to supplement the crazy combo. ICE isn't there necessarily to stop the runner since Midseason needs it, but in the right spots the ICE can be devastating.

name: Momma Said Chakana You Out
description: Chakana is really underrated IMO, it slows the Corp down by making them spend more money and clicks to advance their agendas and it helps slow down fast advance decks. There's plenty of recursion here, between the Deja Vus and Levy AR and clone chips; there's plenty of money to be had too. This isn't the most competitive Noise deck, but it has been a fun one. That moment when your opponent rezzes San San and next turn you drop two Chakanas while Grimoire is out and Surge them is a priceless moment indeed.

name: PPvP/para-recur Kate
description: deck im trying out for a tournament tommorow. toying with a couple akametsu mem chips. please critique and analyze. i feel like i'm missing something other than indexing. im looking at trading out my toolbox as well. built sort of around my meta (hence the lack of indexing, everyone is prepared for it, it's played a lot.)

name: Project Artemis
description:
I have been seeing a lot of archer HB decks.

Behold Project Artemis. My version of this deck, get corroder off the board to create scoring windows. Bluff troubleshooters as agendas in servers with wisp. get money, biotic out agendas.

name: Stupid Super Rainbows
description:
This deck is my first attempt at an Encrypted Portals deck. Though Rainbow isn't the focus, it is not uncommon to have a nice big 7 STR Rainbow or two protecting a server, and it is always funny. The deck is theoretically weak to Shaper decoders, but I haven't had that be the case yet. Mostly, just build up your super-servers, give gifts away to celebrities, and ride the code gates as far as they'll take you!

Changes that I haven't made that could/would make the deck better:

Executive Retreat could probably be The Future Perfect, but I like the goofiness of showing your hand only to entirely change it. It's probably not better per say, but meh, I'm going for fun anyway.

Neural EMP might be better than the Lag Time or the many upgrades. There are a few times that runners will hit your Shi.Kyūs on a last click and go down to 0 or 1 card without even considering the possibility of being flatlined. They also combo well with Archived Memories.

Caprice Nisei could also pretty easily go over a lot of the different upgrades, but she makes people REALLY pissy. If the deck is fun as is, is pissing people off really worth it? Eh, probably, buuuuuut I'm going to leave it as is until I get thoroughly trounced enough to force me to make some changes.

name: Seeker
description: First try at building a deck.

name: Fury of the Sun
description:
1st place Corp deck for the much belated 2014 Season One Tournament at Petrie's Family Games on August 23rd, 2014. Technically a true tie for first place with matching prestige and strength of schedule. Cards were legal up to Upstalk.

Nothing new here for those who have followed PeekaySK's Scorched Imaging or chill84's CSI decks. PeekaySK popularized Scorch in CI and I had particular success with chill84's list, so this build is a near carbon copy of that. This is my third successful Cerebral Imaging variation at a competitive level, but the first time I've brought Scorched Earth into the picture. My local meta has gone away from Plascrete and everyone is used to me playing CI without Scorch, so I figured I would try to surprise a few folks. I went undefeated with the deck, flatlining with SEA -> Scorch -> Scorch in round one and flatlining with Biotic -> SEA -> Scorch -> Archived Memories -> Scorch in round two. In round three I won by scoring out, but could have flatlined with SEA -> Scorch -> Scorch on the same turn. I'm still kicking myself for round four... time was called after I had a runner game go very long in the first game, I got a bad case of tunnel vision with a scored Efficiency Committee and 0 credits, and I scored an NAPD Contract out of hand (double SfSS) for the timed win when I could have used the EC counters to draw credits and play Scorched Earth for the full win. Still frustrated with myself over that one, and that mistake dropped me into a true tie for first place.

Nonetheless... here it is folks, yet another iteration of Cerebral Imaging with Scorched Earth.

Admin Note That should be 2x Subliminal Messaging, not Successful Demonstration.

name: The Magical Equivalent of Zero
description:
1st place Runner deck for the much belated 2014 Season One Tournament at Petrie's Family Games on August 23rd, 2014. Technically a true tie for first place with matching prestige and strength of schedule. Cards were legal up to Upstalk.

I hit a wall on the Runner side of things with Upstalk's release and have been exploring a lot of new archetypes. Nasir is my particular favorite right now, but I have been having a really hard time keeping games short with him and didn't feel comfortable bringing my build into the tournament setting. So I playtested several decks this week and particularly enjoyed GreedyGuts' Rincewind Whizzard build, and sleeved it up for play today with two slight adjustments. My inexperience with the deck showed, but I still stumbled to a 3-1 record with it, beating NBN Making News and Near-Earth Hub decks while dropping a game to a Replicating Perfection glacier build.

My biggest issue with the deck is consistency. The centerpieces of the deck are Desperado and Security Testing, and I rarely found either in my opening hand despite aggressively mulliganing for it. That said, it was a ton of fun to play when it worked, and it was nigh unstoppable once things were clicking.

name: House of Leaves
description:
This RP build is designed to be extremely threatening to the Runner and exploit scoring windows to maximum effect. Nisei Mk.2 and House of Knives combine to provide a snowball effect that allows this deck to carry momentum into the late game. Subliminal Messaging can be an economic all-star in RP, and the effect is only magnified by the addition of Enhanced Login Protocols and House of Knives (both of which often cause to Runner to hesitate and space their runs across multiple turns). Medical Research Fundraiser was found to be much more desirable in this build then Celebrity Gift for several reasons: 1.) Information is too valuable, giving away the contents of your hand ruins the use of cards such as Mushin No Shin and your ICE 2.) Clicks are too valuable and perhaps most surprising of all 3.) the Runner's money is a lot less valuable against this build then you'd think. Mental Health Clinic likewise fell by the wayside when it was found that the drawback of increased runner hand size was a detriment to the click compression and brain damage aspects of this deck and money was never a problem anyway.

This realization is also a big part of the fact that Nisei Mk. 2 gets the nod over NAPD Contract. In this RP build CLICKS, CARDS, and INFORMATION are to be the runner's downfall. Even against a fully developed late-game rig and endless cash resources this deck has beaten Big Rig Shaper by scoring out agendas the old-fashioned way. How is this possible? Simply by controlling the flow of information and providing too intimidating a front to penetrate, an effect that will occur by a combination of scored Nisei/HoKs, multiple remote servers with facedown cards (Ronins waiting for a critical mistake, most of them), ELP in play, and Bioroids and a host of other taxing ICE clogging up the centrals. If the runner only knew which scoring server to go they could win, but the trip through centrals costs them an entire turn as well as most of the cards in their hand... with Nisei Mk. 2 as the emergency reset button to ensure they cannot win even by making the right choice.

Most often by feeding the Runner Fetal AI's and aggressively scoring out House of Knives with the standard remote server shell-game in the early phase you can slow their attack long enough to close the central servers off. Once this is done, with an Agenda (Nisei Mk. 2 most often) that you are ready to try to score, is the right time to play Enhanced Login Protocols. Be ready though because the Runner will often immediately attempt to burn their multi-access events in the hope of snagging an agenda from HQ or R&D to shut down ELP. Punish them with your ICE and make sure the agenda you want to score is not in hand but hidden among your remotes... they almost certainly won't attempt to find it. Use Mushin No Shin to power out Agendas early on or, if you have nothing else you want to score, Ronins. A Ronin is a terrible thing to die to but runners seem find ways to do it out of frustration once they see this deck begin to take off.

This deck wants to move quickly and get ahead because it loves momentum, it's important to remember that to the runner the most intimidating card in this deck bar none is any face-down one. It could be Project Junebug, Snare, anything but what you actually have (that's why I don't bother with those cards, they do their work on the Runner's psyche just sitting in the binder).

'Enter the House if you must, but beware the Minotaur.'
